Key Arguments: The submission emphasizes the importance of freedom of speech as a fundamental value protected by common law and necessary for democracy.
It discusses the limitations on freedom of speech imposed by various laws, including criminal, secrecy, and anti-discrimination laws.

The submission argues that many of these laws may unjustifiably interfere with freedom of speech, particularly counter-terrorism laws and anti-discrimination laws like section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act.
It suggests that some laws, such as those related to secrecy and counter-terrorism, may need to be reviewed to ensure they do not unjustifiably limit freedom of speech.
Notable Quotes: Freedom of speech is the lifeblood of democracy.
The freedom of political communication doctrine in Australia applies to a narrower range of speech, as compared to protections in other countries.
Section 18C of the RDA has been the subject of considerable recent controversy.
Aspects of Australiaâ€™s counter-terrorism laws might be reviewed to ensure that the laws do not unjustifiably interfere with freedom of speech.
